File.Title: Functional and Anatomical Organization of Cardiovascular Pressor and Depressor Sites in the Lateral Hypothalamic Area. 11. Ascending Projections
File.Authors: GARY V. ALLEN AND DAVID F. CECHETTO

Abstract.S: Microinjections of L-glutamate or D,L-homocysteic acid were used to stimulate cell bodies in the region of the lateral hypothalamic area (LHA) selectively.

Subsequent iontophoretic injections of Phaseolus vulgaris-leucoagglutinin or pressure injections of wheat germ agglutininhorseradish peroxidase were made into regions containing identified pressor and depressor sites and their connections with the forebrain and cerebral cortex were traced.

The results indicate that decreases in blood pressure (10-45 mm Hg) and heart rate (20-70 bpm) could be elicited from tuberal (LHAt) and posterior (LHApj sites in the LHA and that these regions have ascending projections to the insular cortex, the ventral forebrain including the septal-diagonal band of Broca complex, the ventral palladium, substantia innominata, amygdala, and the lateral preoptic area.
In contrast, increases in blood pressure (10-40 mm Hg) and heart rate (20-70 bpm) were elicited primarily from neurons located adjacent to the fornix in the perifornical area (PFA).
Injections of tract tracers into this region produced terminal labeling that differed markedly from the pattern seen following injections of tracer into depressor sites in the LHA.
In addition, the pattern of anterograde labeling seen following injections of tracer into the anterior PFA differed from that seen following injections of tracer into the posterior PFA.

Injections of tracer into the anterior PFA resulted in dense terminal labeling in the medial preoptic area and the parvicellular paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus whereas injections into the posterior PFA resulted in dense terminal labeling in the lateral septa1 nucleus, nucleus accumbens, bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, as well as the medial preoptic area and the parvocellular paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus.

The results demonstrate that the posterolateral hypothalamus of the rat contains two regions with specific cardiovascular function and highly organized connections with diencephalic, forebrain, and cortical structures. c1 1993 WiIey-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: This study is part of a continuing investigation of the functional anatomical organization of the lateral hypothalamic area (LHA).
Recently we have described the anatomical organization of descending projections from regions in the LHA with specific cardiovascular responses (Allen and Cechetto, '91).
In this study, we extend these findings by describing the anatomical organization of ascending projections from portions of the LHA with specific cardiovascular responses.
The LHA is an important site for the processing of ascending information from the periphery.

Anatomical and physiological investigations have demonstrated projections to the LHA from viscero-autonomic structures in the brain stem including the parabrachial nucleus, nucleus of the solitary tract, and the ventral lateral medulla (Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Kita and Oomura, '82; ter Horst et al., '89; Allen and Cechetto, '91) and the spinal cord (Yamada and Otani, '78; Burstein et al., '87; Katter et al., '91).

Extracellular recording studies have mapped the locations of neurons in the lateral hypothalamic area responding to baroand cherno-receptors in the cat (Thomas and Calaresu, '72) and rat (Allen and Cechetto, '90a).
In addition, gustatory stimulation elicits changes in firing frequency of LHA neurons (Norgren, '70).

The LHA is reciprocally connected to many forebrain and cortical areas including the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, anterior hypothalamic nucleus, rostra1 portion of the LH.4, medial and lateral preoptic areas, bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, central and basomedial nuclei of the amygdala, lateral septal nucleus, septddiagonal band of Broca complex, nucleus accumbens, ventral striatum, and insular and medial prefrontal cortices (Saper et al., '79; Berk and Finkelstein, '82).
These investigations considered the LHA as a whole without regard for specific functional regions within the LHA.
Thus, the possible function of most, if not all, of these connections is not known.
It is possible that forebrain or cortical projections to the LHA represent the first stage for autonomic outflow to the periphery.
Projections from cardiovascular pressor and depressor sites in the insular cortex are topographically organized in the tuberal and posterior portions of the LHA (Yasui et al., '91).

Furthermore, microinjection of the presynaptic blocker, cobaltous chloride, into the LHA completely blocks cardiovascular and sympathetic nerve responses elicited by stimulation of the posterior insular cortex (Cechetto and Chen, '90).
This suggests that one function of the LHA is to mediate cardiovascular and sympathetic responses elicited from the insular cortex and possibly from other forebrain and cortical sites.

Thus, the LHA receives visceral afferent information, projects to forebrain and cortical sites involved in autonomic control, and mediates descending autonomic signals from the forebrain and cerebral cortex.
It is suggested that these connections of the LHA may be part of long-loop reflexes involved in integration of autonomic and behavioral mechanisms.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Sixty-five adult male, Wistar rats (250-400 g) were anesthetized with intraperitoneal injections of chloralose (100 mg/kg) or chloral hydrate (350 mgikg).
The femoral artery was cannulated and arterial blood pressure was monitored using a Statham P23D pressure transducer and continuously recorded on a Grass model 7 polygraph.
Mean arterial pressure was monitored by filtering the pulsatile arterial pressure with a 0.5 Hz high frequency filter.
Heart rate was determined from the pulse pressure using a Grass 7P44 tachograph and was continuously recorded on the polygraph.
The femoral vein was cannulated for the administration of drugs.
Rectal temperature was maintained at 37 ?
0.5"C with a heatingpad.
Chemical stimulation of the LHA

In 44 animals, the LHA was systematically mapped for arterial blood pressure responses following microinjections of small volumes (5-50 nl) of the excitatory amino acid D,L-homocysteate (0.01-1.0 M) or L-glutamate (0.1-1.0 M) in phosphate-buffered saline solution (pH 7.4).
It was found In the present study, we identified cardiovascular responsive sites in the LHA and described their afferent and efferent connections with structures in the forebrain and cerebral cortex.
Cell bodies in the LHA were selectively stimulated by small injections of the excitatory amino acids, L-glutamate, or D,L-homocysteate.

The anatomical connections of cardiovascular responsive regions were traced following iontophoretic injections of Phaseolus uulgarisleucoagglutinin (PHA-L) or pressure injections of wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP), Preliminary results of this investigation have been presented (Allen and Cechetto, '90b).

that reproducible changes in blood pressure and heart rate could be elicited following smaller, 5-10 nl, injections of D,L-homocysteate (0.1 M) or L-glutamate (0.5 M) and these volumes were routinely used in most of the cases to systematically map cardiovascular responsive sites in the posterolateral hypothalamus.
Single injections of excitatory amino acid were made at 200 to 250 pm steps along each track.
Each track in the LHA (Bregma coordinates: anteriorposterior -3.3 to -3.8; medial-lateral 0.0 to 2.0; dorsalventral 7.5 to 9.5; from Paxinos and Watson, '86) was placed 250-500 pm apart.
Control injections of phosphate buffered saline (pH 7.4) were made into the same sites.

The bottom of the micropipette track was marked either by an electrolytic lesion (1 second onioff cycle, 100 PA, 10 minutes) or by a small injection (10-30 nl) of rhodamine latex microspheres (Lumofluor).
At the end of the experiment.
the animals that were not used in the tract tracing studies were perfused with physiological saline (250 ml) followed by a solution of 10% formal saline (500 ml).
Frozen sections (50 km) were cut, stained with 0.1% thionin, and camera lucida drawings were made of sections through the LHA and the injections sites were identified and plotted.
Tract tracing studies of the LHA

In preliminary experiments a marked reduction was found in the degree of anterograde transport of both WGA-IIRP and PHA-L from sites in the LHA that had previously received injections of excitatory amino acids, especially D,L-homocysteate This is likely due to the excitotoxic efects of excitatory amino acids on the uptake or transport of tracer substances by neurons in the LHA (Olney, '78).

Therefore, the ascending projections of regions that contain identified cardiovascular sites in the LHA were examined by placing tracer substances into the contralatera1 LHA, without removing the micropipette from the stereotaxic manipulator, at the exact coordinates which produced maximal pressor or depressor responses.
This procedure provided the best approximation for the placement of tracer substances into brain sites that were contralateral to the cardiovascular responsive sites.
Injection of retrograde and anterograde tracers were made in 21 rats.

Iontophoretic injections (7 seconds onioff cycle, 5 FA, positive current, 30 minutes) of 2.5% PHA-L (n = 11) or pressure injections of 5% WGA-HRP (n = 10) were made into the LHA contralateral to identified cardiovascular responsive sites.

Animals that received injections of PHA-L were reanesthetized after 7 days and perfused with phosphate buffered saline (pH 7.4, 250 ml), followed by 250 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde in sodium acetate (pH 6.5) and 250 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde in sodium borate (pH 11.0; Berod et al., '81).
The brains were removed and postfixed in the last perfusate for 4-10 hours and then stored in 30% sucrose in phosphate buffer.
Transverse sections (40-50 km) were cut into three series with a freezing microtome.

One series of sections was processed for the immunohistochemical demonstration of PHA-L according to the technique of Gerfen and Sawchenko ('84) with diaminobenzidine, a second series was incubated in a diaminobenzidine-nickel ammonium complex (Hancock, '841, and a third series of sections was counterstained with 0.1% thionin.

Animals that received injections of WGA-HRP were sacrificed after 1-3 days and perfused with 250 ml physiological saline, followed by a mixture of 1% paraformaldehyde and 0.5% glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer (500 ml, pH 7.4).
The brains were removed and placed in 30% sucrose in phosphate buffer overnight.
Transverse sections (50 pm) were cut into series with a freezing microtome and processed by the tetramethylbenzidine method of Mesulam ('78).
One series of sections was lightly stained with 0.1% thionin and a second series was left unstained.

The WGAHRP tracer experiments were necessary to confirm the results of the PHA-L experiments and the retrograde labeling observed in the WGA-HRP studies provided information regarding the sources of afferent input to cardiovascular pressor and depressor cell groups in the LHA.
Camera lucida drawings were made of PHA-L and WGAHRP injection sites and of the distribution of anterograde and retrograde labeling in the forebrain and cerebral cortex.
The PHA-L injection sites were small compared to the WGA-HRP sites and were characterized by Golgi-like filling of cell bodies and their processes.

Labeled processes that exhibited a uniform diameter were assumed to be axonlike fibers whereas varicosities along the path of axons and at the ends of axons and thin stalked-like appendages were assumed to be axon terminals.
The WGA-HRP injection sites were characterized by a dark staining central core surrounded by a lighter staining halo region.

Based on the results of the present study and previous WGA-HRP tract tracing studies (Allen and Hopkins, '89, '901, the central core region was assumed to be the effective site of transport of tracer.
The fine punctate labeling observed in the WGAHRP material was assumed to be terminal labeling and could be readily differentiated from retrogradely filled cell bodies.

Results.S: RESULTS
Excitatory amino acid stimulation of the LHA

the cardiovascular responses elicited following selective stimulation of cell bodies in the lha with small injections of excitatory amino acids were described in detail in a precedingpaper ( see allen and cechetto , ' 91 ) and are briefly described here .

Although we used a few 50 nl injections to locate responsive regions, we routinely used only 5-10 nl injections to identify two distinct groups of cells that elicit specific cardiovascular responses when stimulated with the excitatory amino acids L-glutamate or D,L-homocysteate.

stimulation of cells located in the tuberal ( lhat ) and posterior ( lhap ) regions of the lha elicited primarily decreases in blood pressure and heart rate , whereas stimulation of cells located in the perifornical area ( pfa ) elicited primarily increases in blood pressure and heart rate ( fig . 1 ) .
in many instances , injection of excitatory amino acids 200 to 250 km distal to the initial site resulted in no response or the opposite response to the original .
most microinjections of excitatory amino acids medial to the pfa , in the region of the dorsal medial hypothalamus , did not elicit changes in blood pressure and heart rate .
a few of these sites in the lateral edge of the dorsal hypothalamic area evoked small decreases in blood pressure and heart rate .

thus , it can be seen that the pressor responses observed in the pfa are specific to this region and are not a result of spread of chemical stimulant into the adjacent structures such as the dorsal medial hypothalamic region ( fig . 1 ) .
the magnitude and duration of the responses appeared be directly related to the volume , concentration , and site injection of excitatory amino acid .
The responses to D,L-homocysteate were, in most cases, more brisk than those of similar volume and concentration of L-glutamate.
the decreases in blood pressure ( 1045 mm hg ) occurred within 5 to 60 seconds of the injection of excitatory amino acid and returned to baseline within 20 to 180 seconds .
The decreases in blood pressure were usually accompanied by a decrease in heart rate (20-70 bpm).

increases in blood pressure ( 10 - 40 mm hg ) and heart rate ( 20 - 70 bpm ) occurred within 5 to 60 seconds of the injection of excitatory amino acid and returned to baseline within 20 to 130 seconds .
In 3 of 39 pressor responses, an increase in blood pressure was accompanied by a decrease in heart rate (20-40 bpm).
Ascending projections from a region containing depressor sites
the ascending projections of cell groups in cardiovascular responsive regions of the lha were traced following iontophoresis of pha - l or microinjection of wga - hrp .

preliminary studies indicated that microinjection of excitatory amino acids may inhibit the uptake or transport of the neuroanatomical tract tracers pha - l and wga - hrp ( see allen and cechetto , ' 91 ) .
Thus the tracer injections were made contralateral to the sites where maximal depressor and pressor cardiovascular responses were elicited.

figure 2 ( case a351 shows a representative case illustrating the organization of anterograde labeling following an iontophoretic injection of pha - l into a region containing a depressor site ( see response fig . 2f ) in the lha .

the injection site ( fig . 2e ) contains a dense cluster of pha - lfilled cells located medial to the zona incerta and immediately dorsal to the medial border of the internal capsule at the level of the lhat .
the pha - l injection site is characterized by golgi - like staining of cell bodies and a dense brown staining of the adjacent neuropil .
The degree of neuropil staining can be varied by the length of time the sections incubate in the DAB-hydrogen peroxide solution.

we have found that the actual effective injection site involves only the pha - l - stained cells and there is no detectable anterograde transport from the diffuse brown staining of the tissue around the dab stained cells .
the anterograde labeling observed in this case was predominately ipsilateral .

many labeled fibers swept medially and ventrally from the injection site into the ipsilateral pfa and a few labeled fibers extended into the dorsal and ventral medial hypothalamic nuclei ( fig . 2e ) .

labeled fibers coursed laterally and caudally into the zona incerta , lhap , posterior hypothalamic nucleus , medial and lateral mamillary nuclei , supramamillary nucleus , and tuberomamillary nucleus .
a few labeled axons passed through the dorsal hypothalamic region to enter the contralateral pfa and lhat .
labeled fibers also extended dorsally into thalamic structures .
moderate to light terminal labeling was seen in reuniens , mediodorsal , paraventricular , lateral dorsal , and posterior nuclei of the thalamus .
a few labeled fibers also entered the lateral habenula ( fig . 2e ) .

rostrally , dense terminal labeling was observed extending mcdially from the lha into the pfa and a region dorsal to the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus and extending laterally into the substantia innominata ( fig . 2d ) .
moderate to light labeling was present in the parvocellular portions of the paraventricular nucleus , anterior hypothalamic nucleus , anterior portion of the lateral hypothalamic area ( figs .
zd , 3b ) , and in the central nucleus of the amygdala ( fig . 2d ) .
light terminal labeling was seen in midline thalamic structures and basolateral and ventral portions of the amygdala .

at the level of the crossing of the anterior commissure ( fig . 2c ) , dense terminal labeling was present in the lateral preoptic area ( see figs . 2c , 8b ) , ventral palladium , and horizontal limb of the diagonal band of broca ( fig . 2c ) .
light terminal labeling was found in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , septohypothalamic nucleus , and medial ( fig . 4b ) and lateral septal nuclei .
more rostrally , terminal labeling was predominant in the medial septal nucleus and dorsomedial part of the lateral septal nucleus .

terminal labeling was observed in the cerebral cortex , especially layer v of the agranular and dysgranular portions of the insular cortex and more lightly in layer v of the somatosensory cortex ( areas i and 11 ) .
very light terminal labeling was observed in the somatomotor and frontal cortex ( fig . 2a , b ) , including prelimbic and infralimbic ( fig . 4a ) areas .
the patterns of labeling seen in the forebrain and cerebral cortex following injections of tracer into depressor sites in the lhat and lhap showed no obvious differences .
figure 5 ( rat a10 ) shows the distribution of anterograde and retrograde labeling in the forebrain and cerebral cortex following a representative injection of wga - hrp into the lha .
The injection site (Fig. 5E) consists of a central core (black zone) surrounded by a diffuse spread of the tracer (diagonal lines).
The central core is considered to be the effective site for transport of the tracer.
the core of the injection was centered in the lhap and extended rostrally into the lhat and caudally into the ventral tegmental area and medial portion of the substantia nigra .
the pattern of anterograde labeling observed in the forebrain and cerebral cortex was similar to that seen following iontophuretic injections of pha - l into similar sites in the lha .
the anterograde and retrograde labeling was predominately ipsilateral although there was moderate to light labeling contralaterally .

at the level of the injection site , anterograde and retrograde labeling was found extending dorsally into the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei including the parafascicular nucleus and the lateral habenula .

at the level of the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus ( fig . 5d ) , dense anterograde labeling was present in the lateral hypothalamic area , substantia innominata , the amygdala , caudate - putamen , and the insular cortex .
moderate to light anterograde labeling was located in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus ( figs . 5d , 6c ) and in the mediodorsal and anterior paraventricular nuclei of the thalamus .
retrogradely labeled neurons were widely scattered in the hypothalamus including the paraventricular , anterior , and lateral hypothalamic nuclei .

in the amygdala , dense anterograde and retrograde labeling was found in the central , medial , and anterior cortical nuclei and moderate to light anterograde labeling was observed in the ventral and basolateral nuclei ( figs . 5d , 6d ) .
in the insular cortex , dense anterograde labeling was present primarily in layers v and vi uf the dysgranular and agranular regions .

heavy retrograde labeling was present primarily in layer v of dysgranular and agranular cortices with lighter anterograde and retrograde labeling extending dorsally into the granular insular cortex and somatosensory areas i and i1 and ventromedially into the claustrum , endopiriform nucleus , and piriform cortex ( figs . 5a - d , 6a ) .

at the level of the anterior commissure ( fig . 5c ) , dense anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , particularly the lateral and ventral regions , and in the ventral palladium and insular cortex .
moderate to light anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the medial and lateral preoptic area and medial and lateral septal complex .
dense anterograde labeling seen in the caudate putamen most likely originated from spread of the injection site caudally into the medial portion of the substantia nigra .

rostrally , dense anterograde and retrograde labeling was located in the nucleus accumbens and medial prefrontal cortex especially the prelimbic , infralimbic and dorsal peduncular areas ( figs . 5a - b , 6b ) .
moderate anterograde and retrograde labeling was also found in the anterior olfactory nucleus and ventral lateral orbital frontal cortex .
moderate to light anterograde labeling was present in the lateral frontal cortex .
Ascending projections from a region containing pressor sites
figure 7 ( case a371 shows a representative case of an injection of pha - l into a region containing a pressor site ( see response fig . 7f ) in the pfa at the level of the lhat .
the injection site consists of a dense group of pha - l - filled cells located dorsal , medial , and ventral to the fornix ( fig . 7e ) .

pha - l - labeled fibers extended from the injection site medially and dorsally into the dorsomedial hypothalamic nucleus and dorsal hypothalamic region and labeled fibers passed laterally into the lhat and ventrally and caudally along the third ventricle to terminate in the posterior hypothalamic , supramamillary , and tuberomamillary nuclei .
These projections are predominately ipsilateral.

labeled fibers extended rostrally in the medial forebrain bundle to terminate in the anterior portion of the lha , while other labeled fibers swept medially and dorsally to terminate in the parvocellular portion of the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus ( figs . 7d , 3a ) .

light anterograde labeling was also seen projecting laterally to terminate in the substantia innominata and the central nucleus of the amygdala and coursing dorsally to terminate in the anterior and posterior paraventricular nuclei of the thalamus .

at the level of the crossing of the anterior commissure ( fig . 7c ) , dense terminal labeling was present in the lateral portion of the medial preoptic nucleus and ventral and lateral portions of the bed nucleus of the stria t , wminalis ( fig . 8a ) .
moderate labeling was found in the medial portion of the nucleus accumbens ( fig . 7b ) .
very light labeling was present in the lateral and medial septa1 complex , septohypothalamic nucleus , and infralimbic cortex ( fig . 7a , b ) .

figure 9 ( case a40 ) shows the typical pattern of anterograde labeling seen following injections of pha - l into a region containing a pressor site ( see response fig . 9f ) located more posteriorly in the pfa at the level of the lhap .
pha - l - filled cells in the injection site were located mainly ventral to the fornix and extended medial and dorsal to the fornix ( fig . 9e ) .

anterograde labeling coursed from the injection site medially and caudally to terminate in the posterior hypothalamic , arcuate , supramamillay , and tuberomamillary nuclei and coursed laterally into the lhap and dorsally into the mediodorsal and paraventricular nuclei of the thalamus .

at the level of the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus ( fig . 9d ) , labeled fibers ascended in the medial forebrain bundle to terminate in the parvocellular portion of the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus and the adjacent periventricular region and the anterior hypothalamic nucleus .
labeled fibers extended laterally in the substantia innominata to terminate in the central nucleus of the amygdala and swept dorsally to terminate in the midline thalamic region .

at the level of the anterior commissure ( fig . 9 0 , dense terminal labeling was found in the medial and lateral portions of the medial preoptic nucleus ( figs . 8c , 9c ) and in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( fig . 9c ) .
more rostrally , dense terminal labeling was found in the medial portion of the nucleus accumbens and the lateral septal nucleus ( fig . 9b ) .
in the lateral septal nucleus the labeling was concentrated mainly in the intermediate and ventral subnuclei ( fig . 8d ) .
light terminal labeling was present in the medial septal - diagonal band of broca complex and the infralimbic cortex ( fig . 9a , b ) .

there are several exceptions in the distribution of labeling observed following injections in the posterior pfa compared with the labeling resulting from injections more anteriorly in the pfa , as described above .

compared to the ascending projections from anterior portions of the pfa , projections from the posterior pfa were more dense in the lateral septum , septohypothalamic nucleus , nucleus accumbens , bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , medial part of the medial preoptic area , anterior hypothalamus , central nucleus of the amygdala , and the thalamic paraventricular nucleus .

figure 10 ( case a361 shows a representative case of the distribution of anterograde and retrograde labeling in the forebrain following an injection of wga - hrp into a region containing a pressor site ( see response fig . 10f ) in the pfa .
the injection site was characterized by a darkly stained dense core and a lighter stained halo region .

the central core of the injection site involved most of the dorsal - medial and anterior - posterior portions of the pfa and spread rostromedially into the lateral portion of the dorsomedial hypothalamic nucleus , laterally into the medial portion of the lhat and lhap , caudoventrally into the dorsal and ventral premamillary nuclei , and caudomedially into the posterior hypothalamic and medial supramamillary nuclei ( fig . 10e ) .

as both anterior and posterior portions of the pfa were involved in the injection , the distribution , but not concentration , of anterograde labeling seen in the forebrain was similar to that seen with both pha - l injections previously described ( see cases a37 , fig . 7 , and a40 , fig . 9 ) .

dense anterograde labeling extended rostrally from the injection site in the medial forebrain bundle to terminate in the parvocellular portion of the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus and the anterior hypothalamic nucleus ( fig . 10d ) .
very light anterograde labeling was present in the medial and central nuclei of the amygdala .
light anterograde labeling was present in the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus and moderate retrograde labeling was found in the anterior hypothalamic nucleus .

more rostrally , moderate to light anterograde labeling was found in the medial and lateral preoptic area , bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , and medial and lateral septal complex ( fig . 10b , c ) .
labeling was concentrated mainly in the intermediate and ventral subnuclei of the lateral septal nucleus .
moderate to light retrograde labeling was present in the lateral preoptic area , septohypothalamic , and lateral septal nuclei ( fig . 10b , c ) .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
Excitatory amino acid injections
Determination of the effective stimulation zone following microinjection of excitatory amino acids into brain regions is a potential problem.

Other investigators have injected similar volumes of radiolabeled substances and relied upon autoradiographic labeling techniques to determine the limits of diffusion of the microinjected substances (Spencer et al., '88, '89, '90).
However, this technique does not indicate the region where sufficient concentration of excitatory amino acids are present to induce excitation of neuronal elements.
Another approach to this problem is to microinject small volumes of chemical stimulant at different locations in brain sites and to map the distribution of the various responses.
A measure of the distances between sites that give opposing responses or where the response is lost will give an indication of the effective stimulation zone of an injection site.
We routinely used only 5-10 nl injections of low concentrations of D,L-homocysteic acid (0.1 M) or L-glutamate (0.5 M).
These were the smallest volumes of excitatory amino acids, in our experimental conditions, that could be injected and still elicit a cardiovascular response.

These volumes and concentrations are less than those used by Sun and Guyenet (40 nl; '861, Gelsema et al. (50-100 nl; '871, and Hinrichsen (50-100 nl; '88) and compare favorably with recent chemical stimulation studies by Spencer et al. (4-15 nl; '88, '89, '90).
The close proximity of different cardiovascular responsive sites allowed us to estimate to some degree of accuracy the effective spread zone of the excitatoiy amino acid injection sites.
An opposite response or loss of response was often produced by a similar injection only 200-250 p,m distal to the initial site.
Movement of the pipette back to the original site and injection of excitatory amino acid would then reproduce the original response.

Thus, it appears that diffusion of the chemical stimulant is limited to a range of 200-250 p,m or less and we were able to systematically stimulate and map the distribution and functional characteristics of small groups of cells throughout the posterolateral hypothalamus.
Cardiovascular responses from the posterolateral hypothalamus
The results indicate that distinct groups of cells exist in the LHA and PFA with specific cardiovascular functions.

Injections of small volumes of excitatory amino acids in the posterolateral hypothalamus elicits decreases in blood pressure and heart rate mainly in the LHAt and LHAp, whereas increases in blood pressure and heart rate were primarily elicited more medially in the perifornical region.

In our previous discussion of these cardiovascular responses (Allen and Cechetto, '91), we indicated that the cardiovascular responses can be reconciled with previous reports and for the first time demonstrate the range of responses that can be obtained from a systematic stimulation of all of the LHA including the PFA.
Briefly, our findings are in agreement with those of Sun and Guyenet ('86), who used small injections of L-glutamate to stimulate cells in the PFA of halothane-anesthetized rats.
They are also in agreement with Spencer et al. ('89) who showed significant decreases in arterial blood pressure and heart rate following discrete injections of L-glutamate into the LHAt.

We also observed a few small depressor responses in the lateral portion of the dorsal hypothalamic region that are likely on the lateral edge of a depressor region that has been identified in the dorsal hypothalamic area (Spencer et al., '90).
We did not investigate efferent projections from cells in this site.

We recently demonstrated dense projections from a region containing depressor cells in the LHA to the rostral, middle, and commissural portions of the nucleus of the solitary tract, the lateral tegmental field, and the ventral lateral medulla, as well as the ventrolateral central gray, pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus, and medial and lateral parabrachial nuclei (Allen and Cechetto, '91).
In contrast, projections from a region containing pressor cells in the PFA terminate primarily in the ventrolateral central gray and laterodorsal tegmental region, especially Barrington's nucleus.

These findings indicate that a region with depressor responses in the LHA may influence cardiovascular activity by direct projections to viscerosensory and visceromotor nuclei of the brain stem whereas the descending projections of the YFA to the central gray suggest a possible role in neural processing for pain (Bausbaum and Fields, '84) and defence behavior (Bandler, '82; Depaulis et a]., '89).
Ascending functional-anatomical connections of the LHA

The ascending projections to the forebrain and cerebral cortex from regions containing pressor and depressor sites in the PFA and LHA were determined following iontophoretic injections of PHA-L or pressure injections of WGAHRP into these regions.

The results confirm and extend the findings of previous studies that have demonstrated ascending projections from the LHA to the forebrain and cerebral cortex (Saper et al., '79; Ottersen, '80; Berk and Finkelstein, '82; ter Horst and Luiten, '86).
Figure 11 summarizes the anatomical organization of projections from a region with pressor sites in the PFA and the region containing depressor sites in the LHA.
Major differences were noted in the organization of these projections to the cerebral cortex, ventral basal forebrain, and diencephalon.

The LHA showed widespread ascending cortical projections especially to the insular cortex and the somatosensory, somatomotor. medial prefrontal, and ventral orbital frontal cortices (Allen et al., '9lJ.
In contrast, the PFA showed only a light projection to the infralimbic region of the medial prefrontal cortex.
In the ventral basal forebrain, ascending projections from the region containing depressor sites in the LHA were more dense than those from the region with pressor sites in the PFA.

More specifically, dense terminal labeling from the tuberal and posterior portions of the LHA was observed in the septal-diagonal band of Broca complex, ventral palladium, substantia innominata, and the amygdala.

Injections of PHA-L into the LHA revealed an extensive projection to the amygdala, including dense terminations in the central nucleus and moderate to light labeling in the medial, ventral, and basolateral subnuclei.
In contrast, Berk and Finkelstein ('82) described a limited projection from the LHA to the capsule of the central nucleus of the amygdala in their autoradiographic studies.
The dense labeling observed in the amygdala in the present study suggests that the PHA-L technique may be more sensitive than autoradiographic tract tracing.
Ascending projections from anterior and posterior portions of the PFA differed from each other and differed from that of the LHA.

Ascending projections to the ventral forebrain from the anterior PFA were light to moderate whereas projections from the posterior PFA were dense in the lateral septal nucleus, nucleus accumbens, and the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis.
The LHA, on the other hand, had dense projections to more lateral and ventral structures such as the substantia innominata and ventral palladium.

In the septal complex, the posterior but not the anterior PFA had dense terminations in the ventral and intermediate portions of the lateral septal nucleus, whereas the LHA had dense terminations in the medial septaldiagonal band of Broca complex and the dorsomedial portion of the lateral septal nucleus.

In the diencephalon, ascending projections from the PFA region containing pressor sites were very dense in the medial preoptic area and were light in the lateral preoptic area, whereas those from the LHA were more pronounced in the lateral preoptic area.
In the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, moderate afferent inputs originated from the posterior PFA and only light inputs originated from the anterior PFA and the LHA.
Both anterior and posterior portions of the PFA showed dense projections to the parvocellular paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus.
In contrast, the LHA showed dense terminations more laterally in the perifornical area and in the anterior portion of the LHA.

It is interesting to note that, no apparent differences were observed in the organization of projections to the brain stem from the region containing pressor cell groups in the anterior and posterior parts of the PFA whereas descending projections from tuberal and posterior portions of the LHA did show significant differences (Allen and Cechetto, '91).

Although the PHA-L injection sites in the region of the fornix were small, it is possible that there may have been some anterograde transport from cells located in the dorsal medial hypothalamic region.

Previous PHA-L transport studies have shown that the dorsal medial hypothalamic nucleus has a moderate to dense projection to the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus and the paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus (ter Horst and Luiten, '86, '87).
However, our PHA-L injections in the PFA region produced little or no anterograde labeling in these regions.
In addition, the premamillary nuclei have also been shown to have a dense projection to the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus (ter Horst and Luiten, '87; Luiten and Room, '80).
In the present study, there was little anterograde labeling in the ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus following injections of PHA-L into the posterior portions of the PFA.

This suggests that the anterograde transport from the PFA described in this study originates primarily from a group of cells in the region of the PFA with little or no involvement of adjacent cells in the dorsal medial hypothalamus or premamillary region.
The WGA-HRP injections in the LHA or PFA appear to be large and overlap with cell groups in adjacent regions.

However, our drawings indicate both the effective uptake region as well as the diffusion zone of the injection and in most cases the effective injection site is located within a particular functionally defined region.
The distribution of anterograde labeling compares with that seen in cases with PHA-L injections into similar regions.

Furthermore, the WGA-HRP injections are important because they are necessary for determining the possible sources of afferent input to the specific cardiovascular responsive regions of the posterolateral hypothalamus.
The region containing pressor sites in the PFA and the region with depressor sites in the LHAdiffer significantly in the organization of afferent inputs.

The retrograde labeling seen in the WGA-HRP tract tracing studies indicates that the LHA receives input from the medial prefrontal cortex, insular cortex, nucleus accumbens, septal complex, bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, medial and lateral preoptic area, amygdala, anterior and paraventricular hypothalamic nuclei, and the lateral habenular nucleus, whereas the PFA receives a more restricted input mainly from the anterior hypothalamic nucleus, the lateral preoptic nucleus, and the ventral and intermediate portions of the lateral septal nucleus (Swanson and Cowan, '79; Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Kita and Oomura, '82; Luiten et al., '87; Allen et d., '91).
The differential projections from the regions containing pressor and depressor sites in the posterolatcral hypothalamus to cortical and forebrain regions may indicate their functional significance.

The results indicate that the region with depressor sites in the LHA have extensive projections to cortical regions such as the insular, lateral, and medial prefrontal, somatomotor, and somatosensory cortices.

The somatomotor and medial prefrontal cortical regions have been considered likely autonomic control sites in the cortex and have been implicated in integrating behavioral and autonomic responses (Hoff et al., '63; Cechetto and Saper, '90).
The insular cortex, in particular, has been shown to be a locus of integration of behavioral and autonomic responses (Allen et al., '91).

The insula receives visceral information from the periphery (Cechetto and Saper, '871, diffuse association sensory cortical information (Robinson and Burton, '80a,b; Horster and Ettlinger, '87) and, in turn, sends very specific command signals to the autonomic nervous system (Yasui et al., '91).

We have recently demonstrated that the region containing depressor sites in the LHA has direct descending pathways to brain stem autonomic control sites such as the parabrachial nucleus, nucleus of the solitary tract, ventral lateral medulla, and sympathetic output regions of the spinal cord (Allen and Cechetto, '91) and it has been demonstrated to mediate sympathetic responses originating in the insular cortex (Cechetto and Chen, '90).

However, recent functionalanatomical studies (Yasui et al., '91) have indicated that descending projections from pressor and depressor sites in the insula have topographical terminations in the LHA with little or no input to the PFA.

It is possible that pressor responses from the insula may involve activation of a select group of cells in the LHA that have local projections to the PFA whereas depressor responses from the insula may involve activation of depressor cells in the LHA.

The present results indicate that the region containing depressor sites in the LHA is also extensively connected with limbic forebrain regions such as the arnygdala, substanLs MS DBB s% A BNST VP SI AMYG
MPC LF SCIAI IC -Ls - MS -t DBB - s% + A --., BNST -VP +sI AMYG --t + - MPO LPO -AH + PVH - M A L
MPO LPO AH PVH
tia innominata, and the medial septal-diagonal band of Broca complex.

The amygdala, in particular, has been considered to be a critical site for the integration of cortical exteroceptive information with interoceptive afferents to generate descending signals for coordination of autonomic control (Cechetto and Calaresu, '83, '84).

Thus, it may be concluded that the region containing depressor sites in the LHA is more generally involved in the coordination of signals from cortical and forebrain stem sites that have been demonstrated to be involved in the integration of emotional, behavioral, and autonomic responses.
The LHA, most likely, relays the autonomic signals to the periphery via direct connections with medullary and spinal cord autonomic control sites.

In contrast, the region containing pressor sites in the PFA do not have widespread connections with cortical and forebrain limbic structures but have more extensive connections with hypothalamic regulatory areas such as the medial preoptic-anterior hypothalamic region and the parvocellular paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus.

Many investigations have indicated the role of the medial preoptic-anterior hypothalamic region in regulation of fluid balance using knife cuts and lesions (Buggy and Johnson, '77; Johnson and Buggy, '78; Brody and Johnson, '81; Gardiner et al., '85) and anatomical studies have shown that angiotensin-stained fibers from the subfornical organ terminate in the region of the medial preoptic area (Miselis, '81; Lind et al.. '84).

The paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus is known to be involved in integrating the endocrine-autonomic responses of fluid balance as well as other endocrine-autonomic responses associated with homeostasis (Swanson and Sawchenko, '83).

In addition, the region containing pressor sites in the PFA have limited descending projections that terminate for the most part in the central gray and the dorsolateral tegmental region, especially the pontine micturition center, Barrington's nucleus (Allen and Cechetto, 91).
This suggests that the PFA may be involved in the integration of cardiovascular and fluid regulation in hypothalamic and forebrain sites.
This information may be relayed from the PFA to sites in the midbrain and pons, which mediate defence and pain responses.
The present findings indicate that specific regions in the posterolateral hypothalamus are functionally distinct and have differential connections with forebrain and cortical sites.

The evidence suggests that a region containing depressor sites in the LHA may influence cardiovascular function by direct connections with brain stem autonomic nuclei and that the widespread limbic cortical and forebrain reciprocal connections may be involved in the integration of the autonomic aspects of emotions.

On the other hand, the region containing pressor sites in the PFA may reflect the cardiovascular component of pain and defence responses through connections with the central gray and dorsolateral tegmental region as well as limbic-autonomic structures in the hypothalamus and forebrain.
